text: it was just an ordinary star a
nondescript dot on the fringes of the
Milky Way then it blew up for our moment
the distant star became a gleaming pearl
and the shoulder of the unicorn an
amateur astronomer was the first to
notice it in January of 2002 over the
next few months v838 monocerotis became
a million times brighter than the Sun
and as big as the orbit of Jupiter the
eruption ended years ago but the light
from it has lived on in the form of
echoes as light waves ripple outward
across space from the star they
eliminate clouds of dust and gas around
the star that would otherwise be
invisible
these clouds may be the remains of the
cloud that gave birth to the star four
million years ago
light reflected from those clouds
travels a longer distance to reach our
eyes than the light from the original
explosion it may arrive at Earth months
or years later echo is can last for
centuries the ribbons of gas known as
Cassiopeia A our remnants from a stellar
explosion that would have been visible
on earth in the mid 1600s we can still
detect infrared light echoes from it 350
years later
light echoes are easier to see in stars
like our s papas the so called variable
star that brightens and dims as it
expands and contracts
RS Papa's is surrounded by vast halo of
gas and dust as the pulsing starlight
moves through this halo like a ripple on
a pond we see expanding rings of
reflected light stars might die but
they're light lives on reverberating and
illuminating the dusty depths that bore
them and that must one day reclaim
you
